title: ASIC accused of being 'ideological' over SMSFs
text:
“ASIC’s document is highly misleading and, in some places, arguably wrong,'' Heffron SMSF Solutions executive director Martin Heffron told The Australian Financial Review. "Frankly, from where we sit, it just looks ideological."

Mr Heffron said he had seen very few self-managed super funds with administration costs of $13,900 and the ASIC flyer appeared to be designed to “scare people”.

On the 100 hours estimate, he said: "No trustee in our portfolio at Heffron would spend anything like that much."

Ms Press said the $13,900 figure was taken from claims data provided by the Australian Tax Office.

“The 100 hours is an average,” she said. “Some will spend more, others will spend less.”

Ms Press said accountants and financial advisers often spruiked the benefits of self-managed funds but neglected to highlight the risks.

The risks of under-performance were acute for people close to retirement because they had limited ability to build their balance, she said.

“The Productivity Commission ... identified that SMSFs with balances below $500,000 produce lower returns on average, after expenses and tax, when compared to industry and retail funds.”

Advertisement

ASIC’s flyer says there is a “clear correlation” between the size of a self-managed superannuation fund and the returns earned.

Still, Mr Heffron said the Productivity Commission also recognised that methods for comparing the returns of self-managed superannuation funds with other types of funds were imperfect.

"[Those comparisons] probably shouldn’t be done at all – given the different methodologies. But, if it is to be done, effort and skill is required in order to compare apples with apples," Mr Heffron said.

The Productivity Commission acknowledged the difficulties and its final report sought to deal with concerns raised by the industry.
description: ASIC denies trying to scare investors away from self-managed superannuation funds, after warning last week about the high cost and poor performance of funds worth less than $500,000.
